newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK Windows 97 sellers defy Microsoft.
newsitem.headline: HK Windows 97 sellers defy Microsoft.

text.p: Pirate copies of computer programs produced by Microsoft Corp remained on open sale in Hong Kong on Sunday, despite complaints from the U.S. giant that the sale of fake Windows 97 software was confusing consumers.
Hong Kong had the worst record in Asia for failing to clamp down on the sale of pirated goods, the South China Morning Post quoted Microsoft lawyer Valerie Colbourn as saying.
"Windows 97 is out in the arcades and consumers are completely confused because it hasn't been officially launched in Hong Kong or anywhere else," Colbourn said.
Hong Kong has come under increasing pressure to crack down on pirate software sellers, who ply their trade openly in many of the territory's numerous computer arcades.
Last week, the United States put Hong Kong on the Special 301 intellectual property watch list, a step toward possible economic sanctions if it is not seen to curb copyright theft.

In one arcade named by the South China Morning Post, vendors continued to sell computer disks claiming to contain final versions of Windows 97, the newest edition of Microsoft's top-selling Windows operating system.
One vendor said he was unaware of any complaints over sales of the pirated software, which he said sold for HK$40 (US$5.20).

"It has been selling very well," he said as he wrapped up one disk for a foreign tourist lured into the shop by its large displays of cut-price pirate versions of computer programs, games and pornographic video disks.
One "Windows 97" disk obtained by Reuters appeared to contain only a test version of the programme. Software companies often issue free test versions of new products before releasing them formally.
